topic.title: Support for Right to Left Languages

body.p: The Unicode BIDI algorithm is applied automatically. For best result in HTML, make sure you mark the right-to-left content, or the left-to-right content embedded in right-to-left with proper direction attributes:

body.note: There are built-in rules in the , that automatically match the dir attribute in any XML vocabulary, with the same semantic as for HTML. The accepted values are: ltr, rtl, auto. If you use other attribute names or other values for this attribute, you should add CSS rules similar to the one above.
body.p: For elements in a right to left context, the automatically switches the left borders, paddings, margins with the ones from the right. In this way your CSS is kept as simple as possible.
In the next example, the p element has a border left.

Let say it is placed in a div with default ltr direction. The orange line is painted in its left. But if it is placed in a div with the rtl direction, the orange line will be painted in its right, because that is where the text begins. In a sense, "left" becomes "start".
body.note: To disable this behavior you may use the command line parameter.
